details.description: Unfair agreements between businesses: price-fixing, cartels and reporting unfair practices to the OFT
details.body:
Any agreement that restricts competition in the UK or elsewhere in the EU may be illegal. You can report anti-competitive agreements to the Office of Fair Trading (OFT).

Examples of agreements which can be anti-competitive include:

  • price-fixing (agreeing with any other business on a minimum price to sell goods or services at)
  • limiting production to drive up prices
  • if 2 contracts are put out to tender, agreeing with your competitor to only bid on 1 each
  • agreeing not to sell to a competitor’s customers or compete against them in a certain area

If 2 or more competitors make agreements like these, it might constitute a ‘cartel’.

There’s more information about fair competition and cartels on the OFT website.

Informal agreements

An anti-competitive agreement doesn’t have to be formal, written down or even discussed to be illegal.

‘Shared understandings’, ‘gentleman’s agreements’ and ‘concerted practices’ that clearly restrict competition can also be illegal. Concerted practices are where businesses cooperate without actually reaching an agreement or decision.

Penalties

Your business could be sued, fined or prosecuted if it enters into an anti-competitive agreement. If you enter into a cartel agreement you could receive an unlimited fine or a prison sentence of up to 5 years.

Your business could be fined up to 10% of its turnover and company directors could be disqualified.

Report anti-competitive agreements

The OFT investigates claims of anti-competitive agreements. If you suspect a business is involved in an anti-competitive agreement, you can report suspicious behaviour.
